oai_dc:dc.dc:title: WAVE-INDUCED MEAN CURRENTS IN AQUATIC CANOPIES
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: van Rooijen, Arnold
Lowe, Ryan
Rijnsdorp, Dirk
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Many shorelines around the world are fronted by canopies formed by aquatic vegetation (e.g. seagrass, kelp or mangroves). To date, much progress has been made in understanding how waves propagating towards the coast are affected by these canopies, with a particular focus on wave attenuation (e.g. Dalrymple et al., 1984). As a result, many numerical models currently include formulations to account for the effect of coastal canopies on wave propagation (e.g. van Rooijen et al., 2016).
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 36 (2018): Proceedings of 36th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Baltimore, Maryland, 2018; currents.35
